CatDescriptText: John Coley, barber, 7624 Frankstown Avenue and Harry Williams, barber, 2149 Wylie Avenue, were part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, January 10, 1959, pg. 6 with question: "With Mayor Lawrence performing his duties as Governor in Harrisburg, do you believe the Democratic party in Pittsburgh will be weakened by his absence?" John Coley's answer reads: "I don't think the transition will weaken the party, because the Mayor has so much interest in Pittsburgh because of his home and the renaissance.  He still will have a hand in politics and I think that it will be to the same degree as before."  Harry Williams' answer reads: "I can't see where it will make the party weaker.  If anything Mayor Lawrence still will have a lot to say about the Democrat's affairs in Pittsburgh."
TitMainTitle: Group portrait of barbers John Coley wearing moustache, and Harry Williams, standing in front of door with small wreath and glass that reads "...49"
